awd_titl_txt: Determinantal Rings, Local Cohomology, and Tight Closure
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is concerned with several questions in commutative algebra: this is a field that studies solution sets of polynomial equations by means of studying polynomial functions on the solution sets. Polynomial equations arise naturally in a number of situations, and commutative algebra continues to develop a fascinating interaction with several fields, becoming an increasingly valuable tool in science and engineering. 

The focus of the project is on questions in commutative algebra relating to local cohomology, tight closure theory, and classical rings of invariants; all of these questions arise quite naturally from recent developments. Local cohomology often provides the best answers to fundamental questions such as the least number of polynomial equations needed to define a solution set. Projects in this direction include algorithmic aspects as well as structural properties; there is a special focus on local cohomology modules of polynomial rings over the integers: this stems from the fact that there is a canonical homomorphism from the integers to any ring, and this makes local cohomology modules over the integers, in a sense, universal. This viewpoint has proved useful in recent joint work with Lyubeznik and Walther. At the same time, new techniques for investigating local cohomology over the integers have been developed in joint work with Bhatt, Blickle, Lyubeznik, and Zhang; it is proposed to extend these new techniques to an algorithm. Projects related to tight closure theory include investigating the singularities of Hankel determinantal rings, a question coming from recent joint work with Conca, Mostafazadehfard, and Varbaro, and whether these rings arise as invariant rings for actions of linearly reductive groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polynomial equations arise in a wide number of applications; one fruitful approach to their study is via studying polynomial functions on their solution sets, that form what is known as a commutative ring. This offers an enormous amount of flexibility in studying solutions sets in various settings.

The PI worked extensively with Jack Jeffries, including on a project regarding differential operators on classical invariant rings; the differential operators that one first encounters in calculus make sense in good generality on solution sets of polynomial equations. The goal of the project is understanding these on spaces that include, for example, matrices with various rank conditions. The progress involves a striking connection between lifting differential operators from finite fields to the complex numbers and the study of integer torsion in certain cohomology modules, and then using this to settle a question raised by Smith and Van den Bergh.

Another project, with Hochster, Jeffries, and Pandey, investigates the relationship between classical invariant rings and ambient rings of polynomials; this answers fundamental questions on generic determinantal rings (consisting of the polynomial functions on sets of matrices with rank conditions), and their counterparts, symmetric determinantal rings, Pfaffian determinantal rings, and coordinate rings of Grassmannians.

The PI also had an extensive collaboration with Bhatt, Blickle, Lyubeznik, and Zhang; this includes a project on the cohomology of thickenings of projective varieties of characteristic zero, with strong new results on stabilization properties; another project yielded an asymptotic formulation of the Kodaira vanishing theorem that holds in all characteristics. The relation between these projects mirrors that between Kodaira vanishing and Serre vanishing: the former is stronger, while the latter holds in a broader context. Another project with the same coauthors investigates the injectivity of the Frobenius map on thickenings of smooth varieties over finite fields, with surprising uniformity results.

During the period of the grant, two Ph.D. students completed dissertations under the PI, and took up prestigious postdoctoral positions; the PI also supervised a Masters thesis in Cryptography, two Honors theses, an REU project, and is working with additional Ph.D. students and postdoctoral researchers. The PI co-organized a workshop for graduate students and junior researchers, and delivered expository lecture series at other workshops aimed primarily at graduate students.

The research was disseminated through the arXiv, a free distribution service for scholarly articles, via publications in refereed journals, and via talks at various seminars and conferences. The PI has served as a moderator for the arXiv since 2007.
